If you're looking for something a bit more intense and thought-provoking, "Smilla's Sense of Snow" (1997) might be up your alley. It's a gripping mystery that delves into themes of identity, community, and human connection - all set against the stunning backdrop of Copenhagen and Greenland.

conversation.text: I think I have just the thing for you! Have you considered "The Monuments Men"? It's a fascinating true story about an unlikely group of art historians, museum curators, and soldiers who embark on a mission to rescue art masterpieces from Nazi thieves during World War II. With George Clooney and Matt Damon leading the cast, it's a thrilling and heartwarming film that explores the power of art and culture even in the midst of war.

I think I have just the thing for you! Have you considered "Warlords" (2007)? It's an epic war film that follows a Chinese general as he joins forces with two bandit leaders to take on rebels in 19th-century China. With Jet Li and Andy Lau leading the cast, it's an action-packed ride from start to finish.

If you're looking for something a bit more focused on the American experience in war, "We Were Soldiers" (2002) is another great option. Directed by Mel Gibson, this film tells the true story of the first major battle between US forces and the North Vietnamese Army during the Vietnam War. The all-star cast brings a lot of heart to this powerful drama.

Let me know if either of these strike your fancy!

Tora!", which is an incredibly well-made film that brings to life the events leading up to the infamous Pearl Harbor attack. Or, if you're looking for something a bit more modern, "We Were Soldiers" is a powerful and emotional portrayal of the first major battle of the Vietnam War. Mel Gibson's direction and the strong performances from the cast make this film a must-see.

I think you might really enjoy "A Farewell to Arms"! It's a classic war movie that explores the human cost of conflict, with a beautiful love story at its center. With Humphrey Bogart and Helen Hayes starring in the original 1932 version, it's a timeless tale that will leave you thinking about the themes long after the credits roll.

Alternatively, if you're looking for something a bit more recent, "Proof of Life" is a gripping thriller with Russell Crowe at its center. As a negotiator trying to save his wife's kidnapped husband, he must navigate a complex web of danger and intrigue in South America. With great action sequences and strong performances all around, it's a thrilling ride that will keep you on the edge of your seat!

I think you might really enjoy "The Patriot"! It's a powerful and emotional story about a farmer who becomes a leader in the American Revolution after his son is killed by British soldiers. With Mel Gibson starring as Benjamin Martin, it's an epic tale that explores themes of war, sacrifice, and redemption.

If you're looking for something a bit more thought-provoking, "The Imitation Game" might be up your alley! It's the inspiring true story of Alan Turing, a British mathematician who helps crack the German Enigma code during WWII. With Benedict Cumberbatch bringing Turing to life on screen, it's a fascinating and moving film that explores the intersection of war and personal identity.

It's a powerful historical drama that explores the complexities of war and leadership, with an all-star cast including Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Bruce McGill, and Hal Holbrook. The film's thoughtful portrayal of President Lincoln's struggles to end the Civil War is both thought-provoking and emotionally resonant.

If you're in the mood for something a bit different, I'd also recommend "In the Land of Blood and Honey" (2011). This critically acclaimed drama delves into the complexities of war and its human cost, featuring stunning performances from Branko Djuric and Jelena Jovanova.

I think you'll really enjoy "To Have and Have Not"! It's a classic war drama with Humphrey Bogart, who's simply fantastic as Harry Morgan. The plot follows his character as he helps transport a French Resistance leader and his wife to Martinique during WWII - it's a real nail-biter!

If you're looking for something a bit more modern, I'd recommend "The Last Samurai". Tom Cruise is incredible in this film, playing a tough mercenary who must rescue two Japanese businessmen from a guerrilla leader. The movie takes place in Africa and has some amazing action sequences - it's definitely worth checking out!

I think I can help you find a movie that resonates with what you liked about "To Have and Have Not"!

Based on your interest in war stories, I'd like to recommend "The Hurt Locker". It's a gripping and intense film that explores the personal toll of war through the story of an army bomb squad. Jeremy Renner's performance as Sergeant James is particularly noteworthy.

If you're looking for something with a stronger emotional focus, "The Blood of My Brother" might be up your alley. Although it's a documentary-style film, its exploration of grief and revenge in the aftermath of war could be a powerful fit for what you enjoyed about "To Have and Have Not".
